interpretation_summary: The replication followed the planned approach closely: constructing NAff, IMS, EXS; applying robust outlier screening; creating five-year period dummies; and estimating a country fixed-effects panel regression with period dummies. However, due to incompatibility, two-way or one-way clustering was not used and robust SEs were reported. The replication used an extended dataset (1965–2018, 30 countries) and removed more outliers than in the original. The focal coefficient on lagged imports from the South (L_IMS) was negative and not statistically significant (b ≈ -190.6, SE ≈ 158.9, p ≈ 0.231), diverging from the original positive, highly significant estimate (b = 0.910, SE = 0.104, p < 0.001). Overall, the replication does not support the original claim under these data and methodological approximations.

fidelity_assessment.method_alignment: Substantial alignment with the preregistration: constructed variables as planned; used country fixed effects with five-year period dummies; applied robust multivariate outlier detection (MinCovDet) as an approximation to Hadi; estimated a PanelOLS with robust SEs when clustering was infeasible. The structure mirrors the documented KMYR.do approach (country FE and period dummies) though exact GLS/psar1 and clustering could not be replicated.

deviations.issue_description: Two-way and one-way clustering failed; robust (heteroskedasticity-robust) SEs used instead.
deviations.impact: Moderate: Affects inference precision and comparability to original clustered/GLS SEs; however, the estimate remains non-significant with robust SEs.

deviations.issue_description: Outlier removal approximated Hadi using MinCovDet, flagging 118 outliers (vs. 7 in original).
deviations.impact: Moderate to High: Different outlier handling and a much larger number of exclusions may influence coefficient magnitude and sign.

deviations.issue_description: Temporal and sample differences: replication spans 1965–2018 with 30 countries; original covered 1970–2003 for 18 OECD countries.
deviations.impact: High: Sample composition and period mismatch can substantially alter relationships and reduce comparability.

deviations.issue_description: Estimator differs from original xtgls with serial/spatial corrections; used PanelOLS country FE with period dummies and robust SEs.
deviations.impact: Moderate: Could affect both coefficient estimates and standard errors; direction reversal suggests data/sample differences dominate.

results_comparison.hypothesis_tested: Imports from the South will be positively associated with national affluence (GDP per capita), controlling for exports to the South, unemployment, country fixed effects, and period dummies.
results_comparison.original_results: Effect of North–South trade on national affluence: Coefficient b = 0.910, SE = 0.104, p < 0.001 (positive and statistically significant).
results_comparison.replication_results: PanelOLS with country FE and five-year period dummies, robust SEs: L_IMS coefficient = -190.586, SE = 158.902, 95% CI [-502.664, 121.493], p = 0.231; n = 636 obs., 30 countries, 53 years; outliers removed = 118.
results_comparison.overall_answer: No. The replication does not satisfy the preregistered criteria: the coefficient is negative and not statistically significant.

replication_report: Replication unsuccessful for the focal claim: lagged imports from the South is negative and non-significant in the extended panel with country FE and period dummies (b ≈ -190.6, p ≈ 0.231), contradicting the original positive and highly significant association (b = 0.910, p < 0.001).

failure_handling.suggestions: Attempt to match the original estimator more closely: implement feasible GLS or use Driscoll–Kraay SEs for cross-sectional/time dependence; emulate Stata’s xtgls(psar1) if possible; ensure appropriate clustering (e.g., by country) once model matrix issues are resolved.

Restrict the sample to the original time window (1970–2003) and countries (18 OECD) if identifiers allow; replicate the original scaling and transformations exactly; attempt a closer Hadi outlier implementation or sensitivity analyses on outlier thresholds.

Provide side-by-side models: (a) full extended dataset, (b) original-period subset, (c) without outlier removal, and (d) with alternative SE corrections (clustered by country; Driscoll–Kraay) to assess robustness of sign and significance.

notes: The magnitude scale differs from the original likely due to construction of NAff and scaling of IMS/EXS; while scale affects magnitude comparability, the sign and significance reversal remains. Results may be sensitive to outlier rules and the extended timeframe/country set. Recommend re-running on the original 1970–2003 OECD subset with a closer outlier method and alternative SE corrections to assess whether the positive association re-emerges.
